Oh, `old_row` being negative caused an array overflow, which led to the heap-use-after-free.

This is very easy to reproduce manually
1.nvim
2. :terminal
3. Resize the window rapidly, and observe that it crashes very quickly

No, that's not enough. I do not get any crash that way. So this requires some more specific setup.

(The abort that is likely triggered here checks cursor position, so any cursor settings are relevant.)
Apparently those steps depend on the shell and it's config.

I add the info here, where it belongs as well.

I just noticed that the trick seems to be to make the window small enough so that the prompt wraps to the next line. I did not manage to make it crash if the prompt is not wrapped, even if the scrollback lines are.

`nvim -clean` and a standard bash prompt is enough on my system, but I originally reproduced it with my standard configuration an zsh with a custom powerlevel 10k prompt. Both crashes within 10 seconds of rapidly resizing.
Terminal (settings) rather than shell. In particular, any cursor related options.
Alacritty with default settings. But I can reproduce it in Wezterm and Konsole too, but not XTerm.

So your issue is indeed a duplicate of this one. Rest assured that we'll revert that commit if @leonerd doesn't fix the problem before the 0.10 release (but not before; nightlies are *caveat emptor*).

No, problems. I haven't had any issues with this in practice. It's just something that I found out when testing another Neovide bug. I'm forced to use nightly, since the new smooth scrolling we are implementing only works properly with that, due to the two issues I fixed here recently.

I also thought that this was related to yet another Neovide bug https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/1503, but that was created long before the re-flow was added and the user is on Neovim 0.9.1, so it's a different issue.

> I guess this `old_row >= 0` condition needs to be changed to `old_row > 0`:
> 
> ```c
>     while(REFLOW && old_lineinfo && old_row >= 0 && old_lineinfo[old_row].continuation)
>       old_row--;
> ```

I mailed @leonerd and asked if we could patch libvterm with this fix. His response was

> It's a one character change. I'm sure it's fine.
However, a test would be nice. What condition makes it break?

If someone is motivated to write a test for this and mail that to him then I think he'd accept it.
